etymology.description: Ideogrammic compound: 廌 (“antelope”) + 心; 心 signified goodness, blessings and auspiciousness.
etymology.interpretation: An auspicious antelope/deer associated with prized game combines with the heart to express blessing and joyful feeling, yielding the sense of celebration. Later graphic changes altered the animal component, but the idea of rejoicing over an auspicious catch or event remained central.
etymology.simplification: Simplified in the PRC’s 1956 scheme from 慶 by removing the bottom-right 心 element and regularizing strokes to 大, primarily to reduce complexity; 庆 did not exist as an independent form before.

examples.chinese: 我们庆祝胜利(我們慶祝勝利)。
她为朋友办了庆生会(她為朋友辦了慶生會)。
examples.pinyin: Tā wèi péngyou bàn le qìngshēnghuì.
examples.english: She threw a birthday party for a friend.

examples.chinese: 经历风雨后，他仍心怀庆幸(經歷風雨後，他仍心懷慶幸)。
examples.pinyin: Jīnglì fēngyǔ hòu, tā réng xīnhuái qìngxìng.
examples.english: After hardships, he still feels fortunate.
